title: TRUMP’S FAKE “TOWN HALL” WAS LIKE A BAD EPISODE OF VEEP
content:
To underscore how terrible regulations are , Trump summoned an aide , D.J . Gribbin , special assistant to the president for infrastructure policy , to present a comically large chart meant to illustrate the many rules one would have to comply with in order to build “ a simple highway. ” This being the Trump administration , the highway in question was not an actual highway that had been built but a theoretical one that the Trump Team created so that their boss could have a fun prop to play with . Nevertheless , Donny used the visual aid to make the case that “ getting a building approved in New York is a horrible thing ” and that his administration is going to come to the rescue by “ cut [ ting ] through a lot of red tape ” and spending “ a lot of money on shovels , not other programs . ”
Other farcical moments included Trump—who appointed a climate-change skeptic to run the E.P.A . and last week signed executive orders to roll back Obama-era climate-change regulations—unabashedly touting his record on the environment . “ And we want environmental—we want environmental protection , ” he explained . “ I mean , I have won awards on environmental protection . I ’ m a big believer , believe it or not. ” ( As The Washington Post has noted , while Trump has repeatedly claimed to have won environmental “ awards , ” there is little evidence to support his claim . )
Because there were no reporters present , save for some pool reporters in the back of the room , there was no one there to ask Trump to elaborate on his many plaques and ribbons for environmental excellence .
Speaking of the budding bromance between Trump and corporate C.E.O.s . . .
Jamie Dimon ’ s annual letter to JPMorgan shareholders is out and he ’ s very excited to have a president in the Oval Office who isn ’ t mean to the business community like Barack Obama .
“ Our stock price is a measure of the progress we have made over the years , ” Dimon writes . “ This progress is a function of continually making important investments , in good times and not so good times , to build our capabilities—people , systems , and products . . . . And this is during a time of unprecedented challenges for banks—both the Great Recession and the extraordinarily diﬃcult legal , regulatory and political environments that followed . ”
He continued : “ We have long contended that these factors explained why bank stock price/earnings ratios were appropriately depressed . And we believe the anticipated reversal of many negatives and the expectation of a more business-friendly environment , coupled with our sustained , strong business results , are among the reasons our stock price has done so well this past year . ”
Dimon , a Democrat who was initially tight with Obama before their friendship cooled , quickly took to Trump after the Twitter super-user got elected , saying in March he thought Trump was doing a bang-up job .
Trump ’ s big tax plan is missing a few minor elements
In the wake of the absolute disaster that was the G.O.P. ’ s attempt to repeal and replace Obamacare , also known as the thing Republicans talked about doing for a full seven years , the White House has said it will turn its efforts to the “ big league , ” “ phenomenal ” tax-reform plan that Trump has promised . There are just a few problems . For one , if Trump was apparently blindsided by how “ complicated ” health care turned out to be , why does he think re-writing the tax code will be any more simple ? Then there is the fact that the Treasury Department , which would typically be essential to any such endeavor , is barely staffed . Per The New York Times :
